description: Number of partitions of n into distinct parts, the least being 10.
links: Alois P. Heinz, Table of n, a(n) for n = 0..1000
formula: a(n) = A096740(n-10), n>10. - _R. J. Mathar_, Jul 31 2008G.f.: x^10*product_{j=11..infinity} (1+x^j). - _R. J. Mathar_, Jul 31 2008
example: Say n = 11. There is no way to partition 11 into n distinct parts if one of the least parts is 10 since 11 = 10 + x where x >= 10 has no solutions. Hence a(11) = 0.
maple: b:= proc(n, i) option remember;      `if`(n=0, 1, `if`((i-10)*(i+11)/2<n, 0,       add(b(n-i*j, i-1), j=0..min(1, n/i))))    end:a:= n-> `if`(n<10, 0, b(n-10$2)):seq(a(n), n=0..100);  # _Alois P. Heinz_, Feb 07 2014
mathematica: b[n_, i_] := b[n, i] = If[n == 0, 1, If[(i-10)*(i+11)/2 < n, 0, Sum[b[n-i*j, i-1], {j, 0, Min[1, n/i]}]]]; a[n_] := If[n<10, 0, b[n-10, n-10]]; Table[a[n], {n, 0, 100}] (* _Jean-FranÃ§ois Alcover_, Jun 24 2015, after _Alois P. Heinz_ *)
author: _Clark Kimberling_
